Award.AwardTitle: A Social-Network Study of a Conflict over Pesticide Use

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Divn Of Social and Economic Sciences

Award.AbstractNarration:
This award supports a post-doctoral research project that studies the structure and dynamics of expert networks as they interact with social movements and shape the development of new fields of environmental health. It will identify and map the networks that linked experts to social movement organizations in the conflict over pesticide use in Argentina triggered by the adoption of genetically modified soy, and assess how these networks shaped political mobilization as well as new knowledge on the health effects of pesticides. It will also trace the contribution of non-experts to the development of new knowledge to outline the network that connect all the contributors to the production of different types of knowledge. The study employs in-depth interviews with mobilized experts and activists, archival research, and network analysis; it includes eighteen months of field work in six GM soy producing provinces of Argentina. The results will be broadly disseminated in academic multidisciplinary STS, environmental studies journals and sociology journals; as well as to activists through a summary report that will be sent to media outlets and will be generally available on the project website. An oral presentation of the main findings and conclusions will be delivered in a final workshop with interviewees and other stakeholders in Argentina.

This study will test, refine, and synthesize existing theories of the co-production of activism and expertise within different types of conflicts and settings. Given the potential importance and complexity of the cooperation of environmental movements and environmental sciences, there is a need for research that explores this interaction within a broader scope than most case- study-based research. The study will bring together two theories about expert activism and expertise that have never been brought into conversation, and in doing so it will develop a symmetrical-network theory of expert activism. It will also implement a new symmetrical network-organizational approach to data collection and analysis, and it will test theoretical ideas developed in the US in a fundamentally different national setting in the global South. These innovations will deepen understanding of expert-movement interpenetration and the broader dynamics of knowledge production within environmental conflicts. The results will help environmental health experts and environmental movements to better coordinate their efforts to produce and mobilize different types of knowledge towards solving pressing environmental health problems unrecognized or silenced by the governments.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

NSF Project Outcomes Report

April 14, 2021

 

Project Title: Postdoctoral Fellowship: A Social Network Analysis of Argentina’s Pesticide Effects Conflict
PI: Scott Frickel
Awardee: Brown University
Award Number: 1827910
Award Expires: 12/31/20

 Intellectual Merit

How are scientists and other experts mobilized into grassroots social movements? What impact does their mobilization have in shaping new social policy and giving rise to new forms of knowledge and expertise? This study examines the emergence of expert networks within the popular movement against pesticide use in rural Argentina’s soy-producing regions. Since beginning in 2001, hundreds of communities have mobilized across the country working to restrict or ban the use of glyphosate and other pesticides. During the same period, hundreds of scientists, health care professionals , lawyers, and other professionals have joined the movement, while Argentinian researchers have published hundreds of related academic studies. The movement holds great political significance, not just in Argentina, but globally, as farmworkers and agricultural communities around the world – from Nicaragua to Sri Lanka to Germany – are mobilizing against the proliferate use of glysophate and other pesticides and the impacts of long-term exposure to these chemicals.

 Our study advances understanding of expertise in social movements through two overarching goals. The first goal is to identify and map emergent expert networks and their impacts on social movement goals, strategies, and outcomes. Our second goal is to analyze the impacts of politicized expertise on environmental health and regulatory science.

 The covid-19 pandemic severely restricted in-country travel for research in Argentina and international travel to Argentina. Despite the major setbacks, we have generated a rich bank of unique data on the pesticide conflict. These include two surveys conducted with large samples of mobilized experts (N=148 and 315), a collection of over 400 newspaper articles related to the conflict, and bibliometric data on Argentinian pesticide research (N=1,780 published articles). Although analysis is ongoing, to date, key findings include:

Who are mobilized experts? Our study identifies three profiles of experts participating in the conflict, based on whether they 1) mainly produce scientific knowledge relevant to the movement, 2) primarily engage in movement politics, but not research, or 3) engage in both research and activism. Mobilized experts represent a range of disciplinary and professional domains, including biology, chemistry, agroecology, medicine, law, epidemiology, social work, and education. They also occupy a similarly diverse range of occupational settings where experts’ knowledge claims are advanced and contested. These include rural health clinics and schools, medical schools, research laboratories, university departments, NGOs, government agencies, and law firms. Thus, the network of experts mobilized into the Argentina’s pesticide conflict is large, dynamic, and highly diverse.

 How has expert mobilization changed over time? A related preliminary finding is that the network’s composition has changed over time.  Initially, expert mobilization against pesticides was highly localized, hinging mostly on personal alliances that neighbor organizations had forged with a few local experts. A decade later, expert mobilizations had formalized as a network anchored in the organizational resources of the National University of Rosario and counting more than sixty experts representing villages, towns and cities across the country united by their vocal opposition to pesticide spraying. Since 2011, the Conference of Socio Environmental Health has operated as the main mobilization contexts for expert recruitment and coordination and an incubator of a regional network of experts involved in environmental conflicts across Latin America. These findings highlight the importance of a longer-term and geographically broad perspective for capturing the dynamics of expert mobilization as expert networks are created, merge, expand, contract, and fracture.

 Broader Impacts

Results of the study are helping environmental health experts and environmental movements better coordinate activities that address concerns of rural communities impacted by pesticide exposures. Based on our research, the Argentine Pediatric Society has developed new curricula for training pediatricians to diagnose pesticide related illnesses and to educate rural health workers. The study has also contributed to the training of one postdoctoral fellow and 3 undergraduate research assistants, all of whom are pursuing graduate education in environmental social sciences. We have presented preliminary analyses to audiences at 6 professional conferences, 4 academic lectures and 4 public talks; two review chapters are forthcoming and plans are underway for additional articles and a book manuscript.
